awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Advanced Acceleration Control Methods and Substructure Techniques for Shaking Table Tests
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program project is to develop methodologies that enhance accuracy and capabilities of shake table testing of structures. In particular, this study aims to improve acceleration control methods to reproduce reference accelerations at shake table and to develop substructure techniques to account for dynamically varying boundary conditions. The accurate reproduction of reference accelerations is critical for the investigation of their true impact on structures. By combining feed-forward and feedback control, innovative, high-performance acceleration control methods will be developed through analytical and computational studies. These acceleration control methods will be experimentally validated based on multiple stability and performance criteria under various conditions. Special attention will be paid to acceleration trajectory tracking performance. When partial structural models are tested on a shake table, substructure techniques that take into account interactions with boundary members are essential for the systems level assessment. Substructure techniques for shake tables will be explored using two approaches: 1) inertial force approach, where the acceleration of a supplemental inertial mass is controlled to generate an inertial force that is equivalent to the boundary force, and 2) direct force approach, where the dynamic boundary force is directly imposed by dynamic actuators. Numerical integration algorithms that are required for the substructure techniques will also be developed. Capabilities and limitations of the substructure shake table tests will be investigated through numerical and experimental studies.
  
The results of this research will have a direct impact on earthquake engineering, by providing accurate experimental means for seismic performance assessment of structures under dynamic loadings and boundary conditions. This research also meshes well with the scope of the National Science Foundation, George E. Brown Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation program. The project will provide integrated education and research opportunities for students at all-levels. In activities for K-12 students and the general public, the focus will be placed on linking their knowledge and the project through hands-on laboratory experience. Specific targets include high-school students in the Woman In Science and Engineering Program at the Johns Hopkins University and the Practicum Program at Baltimore Polytechnic High School. At the college level, this research will be integrated into a laboratory for the undergraduate Dynamics course that the PI is currently offering. It will also provide undergraduate research opportunities that help students develop fundamental understanding of theories in dynamics and control. At the graduate level, a new course, "Advanced Experimental Methods for Structures", will integrate the project into the course lecture and laboratory activities. This research will be disseminated through the project website, and the results will be published through a number of significant journals and conference proceedings.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The role of experimental studies is of considerable significance in earthquake engineering. In particular, shake table testing is the primary experimental means for performance assessment of structures subjected to earthquake ground motions. The purpose of shake table tests is to investigate the dynamic response, performance, and failure mechanism of structures subject to reference accelerations. In general, the reference accelerations are either recorded accelerations during earthquake, synthetic accelerations from attenuation and seismological study, or waveforms such as sinusoidal or random waves. However, acceleration control of shake tables is extremely difficult because of an inability to directly control acceleration with feedback, inherent nonlinearities in servo hydraulic systems, control-structure interactions, dynamics of the base support, etc. Improper reproduction of acceleration can result in misleading performance assessments of structural and nonstructural systems. Although measured accelerations at the table can be and have been used as the input acceleration in the performance assessment, it is critical to have an acceptable acceleration control to assess the true impact of the reference acceleration on structures.

Ideal dynamic tests are full-scale shake table tests of complete structural and nonstructural systems. Such complete tests provide comprehensive data sets for local and global seismic performance of structures. However, complete tests of extremely tall, wide, and long structures such as high-rise buildings and long-span bridges are still impossible even with large-scale shake table facilities. In most of the shake table tests of large structures, only structural or nonstructural members of interest (i.e., shear walls, bridge piers, etc.) are experimentally tested. A critical issue in such partial tests is that because interaction between the tested portion and its boundary or surrounding members is not taken into account, test results may not reflect the actual seismic response of members. To investigate the systems level response, shake table tests of a partial structural system need to be integrated with numerical models that represent the remaining of the structure. Such a method is referred to as substructure shake table method and it is a class of real-time hybrid simulation.

This project addressed challenges associated with the above experimental techniques; shake table control and substructure shake table test. The primary research efforts were devoted to advances in structural testing to expand the capabilities and applications of the structural experimental methods. The major outcomes of the project include development and experimental validation of 1) acceleration trajectory control of shake table method; 2) direct acceleration feedback control for shake table with force feedback stabilization; 3) model-based actuator delay compensation technique for substructure shake table method; and 4) force error correction technique for real-time hybrid simulation.

Furthermore, as a part of the research efforts for substructure shake table test method, dynamic force control for structural experiment was extensively investigated in this project. The project team developed a robust loop shaping force feedback controller for hydraulic actuators. Applications and experimental validations of the loop shaping force control were expanded to a series of test systems including a complex multi-degrees-of-freedom nonlinear structural system. The force control techniques developed in this project provide accurate, stable and reliable means for experimental simulation of structural systems under various natural and man-made hazards. Successful completion of this project led to another NSF project on the development of advanced hybrid simulation for assessment of structural systems under coastal surge (PI, Nakata).  

With the support of this project, one student completed his PhD at Johns Hopkins University in 2014. Another graduate student is currently working on her PhD at Clarkson University, expecting to graduate in 2017. Six MS students at Johns Hopkins contributed to the research activities in this project. A total of twenty-eight undergraduate students at Johns Hopkins and Clarkson, including nine female students, were involved in research and outreach activities. A number of outreach activities with hands-on laboratory experience were offered to K-12 students. In fall 2014 alone, 172 students in total from local and regional schools were hosted at the PI’s laboratory at Clarkson. Thirteen journal papers and more than forty conference proceedings have been published to date. 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2016
Modified by: Narutoshi Nakata
